Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my laptop screen illuminating the stack of pharmacy journals I needed to review for the national continuing education program. The deadline for the online module was fast approaching, and I knew I had to stay updated to maintain my license and serve my patients well. My phone buzzed—a message from Mary, a parishioner. She wondered if I might have time to talk, not urgently, but soon. I could sense the weight behind her words; she rarely reached out unless something was truly troubling her. As a priest, I was expected to be available, to offer comfort and guidance whenever my flock needed it. But as a pharmacist, I was expected to be diligent, to keep up with the ever-changing world of medicine. The two roles pulled at me, each demanding my time and heart. I stared at the message, feeling the tension coil in my chest, torn between the call to heal bodies and the call to heal souls, unsure which path to take first.
